basically it is a it's a formula it's a little bit complicated but it's a formula it's meant to compare monthly
revenue gross with growth with lost revenue so what you can think about this is say that this is like a hypothetical company and each
month they're adding this green bar of new revenue and they're losing some revenue from existing customers in these
red bars and so the orange line is like what they net in new new revenue every month this company and this company make
the exact same amount of money every month they're both bringing in the same amount of new revenue but the company on the right is losing a lot they're gaining a
lot more but they're losing a lot more the quick ratio is designed to differentiate between these two
companies if you look at revenue change or revenue growth you'll see the exact same thing with these well the quick
ratio is designed to do is say the company on the Left looks very healthy the company on the right looks like a leaky bucket typically investors much
prefer the company on the Left if you have a situation like the one on the right it's the sort of thing where where
people will always be concerned to sort of no matter how fast you're growing if you're losing a lot of revenue on the other end it's something that will
always make folks worried so this is a good number for you to sort of keep track of for yourself because it's the

after ten months you'll actually be making money from their customers prior to those ten months you're actually just

so that's your payback for you this actually isn't great one just feels pretty good rather the twelve months is
usually considered considered a benchmark that's a good number for for VCS that it's usually healthy to be able
to pay back your acquisition costs over 12 months the reason for that like you may ask like why if I can pay back the
acquisition cost at all even if it takes three years is that not still a positive thing for the business the main reason
for that is it means that you can take money that you're getting from your customers and invest it back quickly enough if it takes you three years to
pay back your cost of acquiring a customer then you're often gonna be in the red for a very long time and as a
start-up you don't actually have that long to be able to do it so it's important to have like a healthy payback
period partly for that reason it also shows that that again you can acquire these customers in a reasonable cost
LTV over kak is a similar number or similar concept but it's instead of comparing how long it takes you to pay
back the customer it's comparing the cost of acquiring that customer with the long term value that you actually get so
LT V stands for lifetime value you want to measure how much what's the race between the lifetime value of a new
customer and your cost of acquiring so we go back to this example again say it's cost you a hundred bucks to get
customers and they pay you ten dollars a month suppose the average customer spends two years buying your product and after two
years they disappear so that means that they pay you $240 so over the course of
a customer's lifetime they're worth $240 to you again it cost you a hundred bucks to acquire them so your LTV over kak
ratio is 2.4 that's actually not great that's the number that it would be a little bit disappointing here to
investors typically the benchmark they look for in this is about three but the expectation is if you're above three
it's pretty good if you're below three it's a sign of concern again for the same reason it means it's hard to scale
it also means that that if things start to change say it becomes more expensive
to acquire customers say that customers don't last for as long as you think they will then you're gonna start to run into
some real unity economic problems lifetime value so it's the lifetime
value of a customer so that's why and the other in this slide they pay you ten bucks a month for two years they'll pay
you for twenty four months or $240 so finally a magic number this is even sort
of more of a in the weeds kind of formula it's basically comparing how much revenue that you bring in

what is the efficiency of that spend relative to your revenue growth that you got from it this is one that has sort of
a meaningless number outside of the value of actually presenting a magic number to investors but typically if
you're below point seven five in this case it's kind of a sign for concern it's a sign that you probably aren't ready to start scaling sales and
